report.report_text:
[Report de-identified (Safe-harbor compliant) by De-ID v.6.22.07.0]
The patient was seen and examined, and the chart was reviewed.
CHIEF COMPLAINT/HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a **AGE[in 50s]-year-old whit female well known to our service with multiple **INSTITUTION admissions for chest pain. She has diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. She has known coronary artery disease with pervious intracoronary stenting. The patient states that yesterday, while sitting in home, she has stabling midsternal chest discomfort associated with some shortness of breath. She has stable dyspnea on exertion. No PND, orthopnea, or increased lower extremity edema, palpitations, or lightheadedness. The patient was brought to the emergency room. She was given two sublingual nitroglycerin. She said there was some relief of the pain, but morphine is what took the pain away. She had another episode last night which responded to Vicodin. She is currently, resting comfortably, sitting in a chair without complaints.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: 1. Coronary artery disease, previous intracoronary stents. 2. Diabetes mellitus. 3. Hypertension. 4. Hyperlipidemia.
CURRENT MEDICATIONS: Please see nursing assessment sheet which I have reviewed.
ALLERGIES: No known drug allergies.
SOCIAL HISTORY: Negative for tobacco and alcohol.
FAMILY HISTORY: Noncontributory.
REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: No significant recent weight loss or weight gain or change in bowel or bladder habits. No fevers, chills, cough, nausea, vomiting, or headache. Chest pain as above, shortness of breath, PND, orthopnea, or palpitations. She has chronic mild lower extremity edema. No palpitations or lightheadedness. No change in vision or hearing acuity. No difficulty with speech. No focal numbness, weakness, or tingling of the extremities. No symptoms of depression. No musculoskeletal aches or pains. All other systems are negative.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: GENERAL APPEARANCE: This is a pleasant obese middle-aged female in no acute distress. VITAL SIGNS: Stable. She is afebrile. HEENT: Head is atraumatic and normocephalic. Eyes: Pupils equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation. Extraocular movements are intact. Sclerae are white, conjunctivae pink. Oral mucosa is moist. No lesions or exudates. NECK: No JVD. Carotids 2+. No bruit or lymphadenopathy. CHEST: Clear lung fields to auscultation and percussion bilaterally. CARDIAC: Precordium is quiet. PMI nondisplaced. Regular rate and rhythm. S1, S2. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. ABDOMEN: Soft, nontender. Positive bowel sounds. No hepatosplenomegaly. No masses or bruits. EXTREMITIES: No clubbing, cyanosis, or edema. Peripheral pulses are full. Edema 2+ bilaterally. NEUROLOGIC: She is alert and oriented to time. No focal neurological deficits.
LABORATORY DATA: Admission laboratories were reviewed.
IMPRESSION: The patient was admitted with chest pain was clinically atypical for angina pectoris. The patient has had multiple previous **INSTITUTION admissions for similar complaints of chest pain which usually responds to narcotics rather than nitrates. The patient however, does have multiple cardiac risk factors including diabetes, and she has known coronary artery disease with previous intracoronary stents. Her last stress test was 3 years ago. Because of her multiple risk factors despite atypical nature of the pain, her normal EKG and negative enzymes we will proceed with a stress test today. If this is negative, the patient will be discharged home. Her blood pressure is adequately controlled, and she is on a statin for dyslipidemia.
Thanks for this consultation.
______________________________ **NAME[WWW M. XXX], M.D.
HS Job # 926600 / 39810 / # **ID-NUM D: **DATE[Apr 24 2007] 12:31 T: **DATE[Apr 25 2007] 02:52
